options.label: A.
options.text: is the liquid in which solvent is dissolved in.

options.label: B.
options.text: is the major component of a solution.

options.label: C.
options.text: may exist as a solid, liquid, or gas.

options.label: E.
options.text: is always present in a larger quantity than the solvent.

correct_answer_text: may exist as a solid, liquid, or gas.

explanation.concept_text: Option A. is the liquid in which solvent is dissolved in. Incorrect. The solute is the substance that is dissolved in the solvent. Option B. is the major component of a solution. Incorrect. The solute is the minor component of a solution. Option C. may exist as a solid, liquid, or gas. Correct. Although solutes are commonly thought of as solids that dissolve in a liquid solvent, remember that solutes can also exist as a solid, liquid, or gas. Option D. always remains unchanged. Incorrect. Solutes are oftentimes changed in a solution – whether they dissociate, react, precipitate, or decompose. Option E. is always present in a larger quantity than the solvent. Incorrect. Solutes are present in a smaller quantity than the solvent in a solution. Therefore, the answer is C .

question.text: Which of the following statements best describes an unsaturated solution?

options.label: A.
options.text: It has not dissolved the maximum amount of solute possible

options.label: B.
options.text: It quickly precipitates when solute is added to the solvent

options.label: C.
options.text: It contains a high concentration of electrolytes

options.label: D.
options.text: It contains higher concentration of the solute than its solubility limit

options.label: E.
options.text: It always has a high boiling point

correct_answer_text: It has not dissolved the maximum amount of solute possible

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving solubility , we need to know that unsaturated solutions are solutions that can dissolve more solute if additional solute is added. In other words, unsaturated solutions are solutions that has not dissolved the maximum amount of solute possible. Therefore, the answer is A .

question.text: A solution that has a solute that is no longer being dissolved and begins to settle at the bottom of a beaker. The solution would be best classified as

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving solubility , we need to know that saturated solutions are solutions in which the maximum amount of solute has been dissolved. Therefore, we can say that a solution that has a solute that is no longer being dissolved and begins to settle at the bottom of a beaker is a saturated solution. Therefore, the answer is E .

question.text: Which of the following is not typically a component of a soluble salt?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving solubility , we will need to know some common chemical compounds that often form soluble and insoluble salts: Soluble salts Insoluble salts Group 1 metal cations Ag + NO 3 - Pb 2+ , Hg 2+ ClO 4 - OH - C 2 H 3 O 2 - S 2- NH 4 + CO 3 2- , PO 4 3- In this case, Li + , Na + , K + , and Rb + are all Group 1 metal cations that can form soluble salts. Because H + is not a Group 1 metal cation, it is not typically a component of a soluble salt. Therefore, the answer is A .

question.text: Which of the following molecules is insoluble in water?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving solubility , we will need to know some common chemical compounds that often form soluble and insoluble salts: Soluble salts Insoluble salts Group 1 metal cations Ag + NO 3 - Pb 2+ , Hg 2+ ClO 4 - OH - C 2 H 3 O 2 - S 2- NH 4 + CO 3 2- , PO 4 3- In this case, AgCl contains Ag + , which is an insoluble salt component, making AgCl insoluble in water. Option A. NaCl Incorrect. Na + is under the list of soluble salts. Cl - does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. Therefore, NaCl is soluble in water because it has one component that is soluble. Option B. KNO 3 Incorrect. K + is under the list of soluble salts (Group 1 metal cations). NO 3 - is also under the list of soluble salts. Therefore, KNO 3 is soluble in water. Option C. AgCl Correct. Ag + is under the list of insoluble salts. Cl - does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. Therefore, AgCl is insoluble in water. Option D. CsF Incorrect. Cs + is under the list of soluble salts. F - does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. Therefore, CsF is soluble in water. Option E. NH 4 NO 3 Incorrect. NH 4 + is under the list of soluble salts. NO 3 - is under the list of soluble salts. Therefore, NH 4 NO 3 is soluble in water. Therefore, the answer is C .

question.text: Which of the following salts is not soluble in water under normal conditions?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving solubility , we will need to know some common chemical compounds that often form soluble and insoluble salts: Soluble salts Insoluble salts Group 1 metal cations Ag + NO 3 - Pb 2+ , Hg 2+ ClO 4 - OH - C 2 H 3 O 2 - S 2- NH 4 + CO 3 2- , PO 4 3- In this case, PbCO 3 contains both Pb 2+ and CO 3 2- , which are both insoluble salt components, so we know that PbCO 3 is insoluble in water. Option A. Na 3 PO 4 Incorrect. Na + is under the list of soluble salts. PO 4 3- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, Na 3 PO 4 is soluble in water because of the predominance of its soluble components when a salt contains both soluble and insoluble components. Option B. Ag 3 NO 3 Incorrect. Ag + is under the list of insoluble salts. NO 3 - is under the list of soluble salts. Therefore, Ag 3 NO 3 is soluble in water because of the predominance of its soluble components when a salt contains both soluble and insoluble components. Option C. (NH 4 ) 3 PO 4 Incorrect. NH 4 + is under the list of soluble salts. PO 4 3- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, (NH 4 ) 3 PO 4 is soluble in water because of the predominance of its soluble components when a salt contains both soluble and insoluble components. Option D. PbCO 3 Correct. Pb 2+ is under the list of insoluble salts. CO 3 2- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, PbCO 3 is insoluble in water. Option E. NH 4 NO 3 Incorrect. NH 4 + is under the list of soluble salts. NO 3 - is under the list of soluble salts. Therefore, NH 4 NO 3 is soluble in water. Therefore, the answer is D .

question.text: For the addition of Pb(OH) 2 and Hg(OH) 2 in water to form a solution, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: D.
options.text: Both Pb(OH) 2 and Hg(OH) 2 do not dissolve

options.label: E.
options.text: Pb(OH) 2 and Hg(OH) 2 form complexes together

correct_answer_text: Both Pb(OH) 2 and Hg(OH) 2 do not dissolve

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving solubility , we will need to know some common chemical compounds that often form soluble and insoluble salts: Soluble salts Insoluble salts Group 1 metal cations Ag + NO 3 - Pb 2+ , Hg 2+ ClO 4 - OH - C 2 H 3 O 2 - S 2- NH 4 + CO 3 2- , PO 4 3- In this case, both Pb(OH) 2 and Hg(OH) 2 are insoluble salts because they contain Pb 2+ ,Hg 2+ , and OH - . This means that both Pb(OH) 2 and Hg(OH) 2 do not dissolve in water. Therefore, the answer is D .

question.text: Which of the following salts is the most soluble in water?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving solubility , we will need to know some common chemical compounds that often form soluble and insoluble salts: Soluble salts Insoluble salts Group 1 metal cations Ag + NO 3 - Pb 2+ , Hg 2+ ClO 4 - OH - C 2 H 3 O 2 - S 2- NH 4 + CO 3 2- , PO 4 3- In this case, NaOH contains Na + (group 1 metal cation), so we know that NaOH is soluble in water because of the predominance of its soluble components (Na + ) when a salt contains both soluble (Na + ) and insoluble components (OH - ). Option A. NaOH Correct. Na + is under the list of soluble salts. OH - is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, NaOH is soluble in water because it has one component that is soluble. Option B. Mg(OH) 2 Incorrect. Mg 2+ does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. OH - is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, Mg(OH) 2 is insoluble in water. Option C. Al(OH) 3 Incorrect. Al 3+ does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. OH - is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, Al(OH) 3 is insoluble in water. Option D. PbSO 4 Incorrect. Pb 2+ is under the list of insoluble salts. SO 4 2- does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. Therefore, PbSO 4 is insoluble in water. Option E. AgBr Incorrect. Ag + is under the list of insoluble salts. Br - does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. Therefore, AgBr is insoluble in water. Therefore, the answer is A .

question.text: Which of the following carbonate salts is most soluble in water?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving solubility , we will need to know some common chemical compounds that often form soluble and insoluble salts: Soluble salts Insoluble salts Group 1 metal cations Ag + NO 3 - Pb 2+ , Hg 2+ ClO 4 - OH - C 2 H 3 O 2 - S 2- NH 4 + CO 3 2- , PO 4 3- In this case, K 2 CO 3 contains K + (soluble component) and CO 3 2- (insoluble component). So we know that K 2 CO 3 is soluble in water because of the predominance of its soluble components (K + ) over its insoluble components (CO 3 2- ). Option A. K 2 CO 3 Correct. K + is under the list of soluble salts. CO 3 2- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, K 2 CO 3 is soluble in water because it has one component that is soluble. Option B. CuCO 3 Incorrect. Cu 2+ does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. CO 3 2- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, CuCO 3 is insoluble in water. Option C. MnCO 3 Incorrect. Mn 2+ does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. CO 3 2- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, MnCO 3 is insoluble in water. Option D. Ag 2 CO 3 Incorrect. Ag + is under the list of insoluble salts. CO 3 2- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, AgCO 3 is insoluble in water. Option E. FeCO 3 Incorrect. Fe 2+ does not appear under soluble nor insoluble salts. CO 3 2- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, FeCO 3 is insoluble in water. Therefore, the answer is A .

question.text: Which of the following salts is soluble in water?

explanation.concept_text: To solve this problem involving solubility , we will need to know some common chemical compounds that often form soluble and insoluble salts: Soluble salts Insoluble salts Group 1 metal cations Ag + NO 3 - Pb 2+ , Hg 2+ ClO 4 - OH - C 2 H 3 O 2 - S 2- NH 4 + CO 3 2- , PO 4 3- In this case, Pb(NO 3 ) 2 contains Pb 2+ (insoluble component) and NO 3 - (soluble component). So we know that Pb(NO 3 ) 2 is soluble in water because of the predominance of its soluble components (NO 3 - ) over its insoluble components (Pb 2+ ). Option A. PbS Incorrect. Pb 2+ is under the list of insoluble salts. S 2- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, PbS is insoluble in water. Option B. Pb(NO 3 ) 2 Correct. Pb 2+ is under the list of insoluble salts. NO 3 2- is under the list of soluble salts. Therefore, Pb(NO 3 ) 2 is soluble in water because it has one component that is soluble. Option C. AgOH Incorrect. Ag + is under the list of insoluble salts. OH - is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, AgOH is insoluble in water. Option D. Ag 2 CO 3 Incorrect. Ag + is under the list of insoluble salts. CO 3 2- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, Ag 2 CO 3 is insoluble in water. Option E. HgS Incorrect. Hg 2+ is under the list of insoluble salts. S 2- is under the list of insoluble salts. Therefore, HgS is insoluble in water. Therefore, the answer is B .
